awd_titl_txt: Georgia - Alabama Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation
awd_abstract_narration:
The GALSAMP is comprised of nine institutions. The program plans to significantly increase the number or underrepresented minorities in STEM receiving baccalaureate degrees in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. An important element of the plan is an early and sustained exposure of undergraduates to research training throughout the undergraduate experience. The alliance expects to significantly contribute to GALSAMP schools of increasing the quantity and quality of minority students in STEM disciplines and to ensuring their entry into graduate programs. The program also seeks to improved recruitment, retention, community college student transfer, and graduation for underrepresented students in STEM. The project has the following goals:
- Increase the number of students recruited into STEM majors by 50% over five-years.
- Increase persistence and progression of STEM students in the expanded alliance to 85% over five-years.
- Increase the number of STEM students transferring from alliance two-year community colleges to four-year baccalaureate alliance institutions from 31% to 50% over five years.
- Increase the number of STEM baccalaureate graduates from the 2012 baseline total by 100% from 380 to 760 over five years.
- Increase the number of STEM Baccalaureate graduates who compete successfully for entry into graduate degree programs from 40% to 80% over five-years.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report – NSF Award # 1305041

Project TITLE:  Georgia-Alabama Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation

Recipient Organization: Clark Atlanta University

Project/Grant Period: 09/01/2013 – 08/31/2020

PI:  Georgia w. French Jr. Ph.D.

The Georgia-Alabama Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation program (GA-AL LSAMP) is comprised of nine partner institutions, namely, Clark Atlanta University, Atlanta Metropolitan State College, Georgia State University, J. F. Drake State Community and Technical College, Lawson State Community College, Morehouse College, Spelman College, Paine College, and the University of West Georgia.  The GA-AL LSAMP program goals were to catalyze a progressive increase in the number of underrepresented minority students at alliance institutions, who were enrolled and completed BS degrees in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) areas and who go on to pursue graduate degrees in these areas. This was to be achieved through engagement and mentoring of students in their co-curricular undergraduate STEM research and related professional development activities.

 The alliance partners worked collaboratively toward achieving these goals over the project period. The program provided opportunities for approximately 120 underrepresented minority undergraduate STEM majors (LSAMP scholars) per year to participate in academic-year STEM related co-curricular research activities at all 9 alliance participating institutions.  The LSAMP scholars received ongoing mentoring and financial support in their scientific research and related activities under the guidance of STEM faculty and graduate students. Scholars attended several local, regional and national scientific research conferences (including the annual GA-AL LSAMP Research Symposium) and delivered oral and poster presentations of their research, and established professional network and connections with their peers from other institutions and organizations.  Scholars participated in GA-AL LSAMP annual professional develop workshop at which they were interactively engaged in exploring topics, such as growth mindset, conducting scientific research, preparing and presenting oral and poster presentations, STEM career opportunities, preparing for graduate schools, and time management. Scholars were also engaged in peer mentoring and attended summer REUs and other internships at various research-intensive institutions. Over the project period, the LSAMP scholars consistently demonstrated very high success rates in completing BS degrees in STEM and a significant number go on to enroll in graduate programs. With respect to the alliance - wide overall minority STEM population, the minority enrollment in STEM increased from 5474 to 7486 (37 %) and the number of BS degrees awarded to minority students increased from 581 to 991 (70 %) between academic years 2014 and 2019.

 


Last Modified: 01/07/2021
Modified by: Conrad W Ingram
